channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Allies Pile Pressure on Germany Over Tanks for Ukraine
item.description: During a break at a meeting of Ukraine’s allies, led by the United States, Germany’s defense minister says there is still no consensus on sending the Leopard 2 main battle tank.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The graves of unidentified soldiers in the military section of a cemetery in Dnipro, Ukraine.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern Will Be Gone Soon but New Zealand’s Economic Troubles Are Here to Stay
item.description: Ms. Ardern maneuvered through one crisis after another but had less success confronting persistent challenges that have hobbled successive governments.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The skyline of Auckland, New Zealand.

item.title: For Reporter, Trauma Comes With Exposing Ugly Truths of a Brutal Conflict
item.description: Mariam Ouédraogo is the first female African journalist to win the world’s top prize for war correspondents, but covering the sexual violence in Burkina Faso has given her PTSD.
item.dc:creator: Clair MacDougall
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Clair MacDougall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariam Ouédraogo won the Bayeux Calvados-Normandy Award for her series reporting on Burkina Faso’s devastating conflict against armed jihadist groups and the suffering the fighting has inflicted on the country’s women and girls.

item.title: Israel’s Judicial Standoff Deepens as Netanyahu Delays Firing Minister
item.description: The Israeli prime minister has yet to uphold a decision by the Supreme Court that a key government minister convicted of tax fraud should be dismissed.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, center, walked out of the home of his ally Aryeh Deri, the interior minister and the head of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party, in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Australian Man Takes 3,000-Mile Detour Because of a Flood
item.description: Few roads crisscross Western Australia, so when a single one is closed, there can be serious complications. Ask Chris English.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Chris English’s Nissan Patrol, somewhere in the Australian outback.

item.title: The Debate Over Sending Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: Western nations are amping up offensive military power for Ukraine in almost every category except the one Kyiv says it needs the most. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank outside the city of Bakhmut in December.

item.title: Workers in France Strike Over Macron’s Plan to Raise Retirement Age
item.description: Despite the wave of discontent, President Emmanuel Macron intends to push through plans to raise the retirement age to 64 from 62.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Union leaders and protesters marching in Paris on Thursday. Those striking included teachers, railway workers and employees at public radio stations and oil refineries.

item.title: Tunisian Cave Village Empties Out in Face of Drought and Modernity’s Draw
item.description: For 1,000 years, homes dug into a desert cliff have sheltered olive farmers and sheep herders from summer heat and winter cold. But an exodus threatens its future. “We are left alone here.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Zied Ben Romdhane for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cave village of Chenini in Tunisia’s southern desert.

item.title: South Africa to Hold Naval Drill With Russia and China Amid Ukraine War
item.description: The 10-day naval exercises are a show of diplomatic independence for South Africa, which is part of an alliance with Brazil, Russia, India and China — known as BRICS.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
item.media:description: A sanctioned Russian container ship, center left, docked in South Africa’s naval port outside Cape Town, last month.

item.title: More Evidence of Indigenous Children’s Graves Is Found in Canada
item.description: The finding, announced by the Anishinabe of Wauzhushk Onigum Nation, comes from one of several searches underway at former Indigenous schools across Canada.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for 215 children found buried in unmarked graves near the Kamloops Residential School in British Columbia in 2021.

item.title: On These Small Islands, Medical Care Arrives One Ship at a Time
item.description: Much of rural South Korea has seen its population rapidly decline and age. For some communities off the coast, doctors traveling by boat have become a lifeline for the old and sick.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Chang W. Lee
item.media:description: Kim Wong-chae, 85, left, and other residents of Hodo island on the way to Chungnam 501, a government-run hospital ship that brings medical service to remote, doctor-less islands, in July.

item.title: A Secret Room and a Comfortable Life: A Mobster’s Years on the Run
item.description: Since the arrest earlier this week of Matteo Messina Denaro, a picture of his time on the lam is starting to take shape.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Judge Maria Carmela Giannazzo conducting a hearing on Thursday for Matteo Messina Denaro in Caltanissetta, Sicily.

item.title: How Covid Played a Role in Jacinda Ardern’s Resignation
item.description: In a part of the world where coronavirus restrictions lingered, Jacinda Ardern struggled to get beyond her association with pandemic policy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand last year. She won global fame with youthful charisma and a frank, compassionate leadership style that carried her through crisis but has since announced her resignation.

item.title: Sister André, World’s Oldest Known Person, Dies at 118
item.description: A French nun, she lived through two world wars and the 1918 flu pandemic and, more than a century later, survived Covid-19. She enjoyed a bit of wine and chocolate daily.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Sister André at the Ste. Catherine Labouré nursing home in Toulon, France, last year. She was known for her generosity.

item.title: 1898: Anglo-Siberian Trade
item.description: A Russian tariff on imports to Siberia was under discussion.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Debt Ceiling Fight Is Putting U.S. Economy at Risk
item.description: A political fight is again putting the economy at risk.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: The Department of Treasury on Thursday.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern Exits the Stage
item.description: After the surprise had sunk in, speculation about her next move quickly began. The answer may lie in the priorities she professed before becoming prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mark Mitchell/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern hugged her fiancé, Clarke Gayford, on Thursday after she announced she would step down as prime minister.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A meeting in Germany of Ukraine’s allies.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Leopard 2 tanks. Allies are pressuring Germany to allow them to be supplied to Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine’s Allies Pledge to Send Major Infusion of Military Aid
item.description: As representatives from dozens of countries prepared to attend a war-planning meeting in Germany, the talk was of missiles, air defense and — above all — tanks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Eric Schmitt, Lara Jakes and Erika Solomon
item.media:description: A Ukrainian tank firing at Russian positions in the Luhansk region last week.

item.title: CIA Director Burns Visited Ukraine to Meet With Zelensky
item.description: The director, William J. Burns, has made periodic visits to Ukraine to meet with intelligence officials and to exchange information with the country’s president.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, in Washington in 2021.

item.title: Trump’s Interior Secretary Didn’t Violate Ethics Rules, Watchdog Finds
item.description: An inspector general’s report found no evidence that David Bernhardt had improperly favored a group that once employed him as a lobbyist.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: David Bernhardt, who was Interior Secretary during the Trump administration, spent 10 years as a lobbyist for the Westlands Water District before leading the Interior department.

item.title: What Is the Leopard 2 Tank, and How Could It Help Ukraine?
item.description: One of the world’s leading battle tanks, the German-made Leopard 2 has sophisticated targeting capabilities, even in rough terrain.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A German Leopard tank during a NATO military exercise held in Lithuania last October.

item.title: A Bus Driver’s Ode to His Job Is a Surprise Music Video Hit
item.description: The video features Ranjit Singh Veer driving his bus in the West Midlands of Britain and leading a Punjabi bhangra dance crew. It has drawn tens of thousands of views in the last week.
item.dc:creator: Emily Schmall

item.title: The Met’s Maya Show Asks: Can Art Ever Be Innocent?
item.description: A riveting show at the Metropolitan Museum surveys the complicated art of the ancient Maya, in which beauty and brutality are surreally entangled.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Lives of the Gods: Divinity in Maya Art” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art has more than 100 objects, a Mesoamerican survey of a scale not seen in years. Left, Monument 155 and Monument 180 feature sculptures of captured Lords impersonating jaguar deities, 700 A.D.

item.title: India’s Love Story With ‘D.D.L.J.’ Is Still Strong After 27 Years
item.description: ‘D.D.L.J.,’ which a Mumbai theater has shown nearly every day since 1995, encapsulates a society in churn, with the choices afforded by economic opportunity clashing with tradition.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
item.media:description: A woman who goes by the name Simran has become a regular at screenings of “Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge” at the Maratha Mandir cinema in Mumbai.

item.title: At Least One Dead in Iraq After Stampede Outside Soccer Stadium
item.description: Thousands of fans thronged an arena in the southern city of Basra for a match involving the national team. Many were angry to discover that they had been sold fake tickets, a witness said.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: A security team carried an injured fan into an emergency area at the stadium in Basra on Thursday.

item.title: How the Pandemic May Have Cleared the Way for Casinos in NYC
item.description: The pandemic may finally have cleared the way for a casino in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Manhattan.

item.title: Whitney Curator Marcela Guerrero Leads the Way on Latino Art
item.description: In her five years at the museum, Marcela Guerrero has helped broaden the scope of artists and audiences as the Hispanic population continues to grow and museums try to reflect more diverse audiences.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Sabrina Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marcela Guerrero, an associate curator at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, is leading the way in the field of Latino art. She stands in front of a favorite painting, Robert Henri’s “Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney” (1916).

item.title: How Do California’s Storms Weigh In Compared With History’s Big Ones?
item.description: Rain and snowfall this season are above average, but the state has seen some wild weather in past years.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Mira Rojanasakul
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists braved the elements near the Golden Gate Bridge on Dec. 31.

item.title: Could Air Someday Power Your Flight? Airlines Are Betting on It.
item.description: New technologies, including one fuel extracted from the atmosphere itself, could make flying more sustainable. But the challenges are many and the timeline is uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Paige McClanahan

item.title: Key Moments in Jacinda Ardern’s Political Career
item.description: New Zealand’s outgoing prime minister won global fame with youthful charisma and a frank, compassionate leadership style that carried her through crisis.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern in October 2017, soon after her party won the election that would make her prime minister.

item.title: Ukraine Will Investigate the Cause of a Deadly Helicopter Crash
item.description: The helicopter came down near a kindergarten and a residential building outside Kyiv, killing the interior minister and others and causing severe damage.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Metin Aktas/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Ukraine’s interior minister, Denys Monastryrsky, in the town of Borodianka after Ukrainian forces retook it last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A helicopter crash in Ukraine and the resignation of Jacinda Ardern.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Metin Aktas/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Denys Monastyrsky, Ukraine’s minister for internal affairs, died in the crash.

item.title: Helicopter Crash Kills Ukrainian Minister in Blow to Wartime Leadership
item.description: The crash in a suburb of Kyiv killed at least 14 people, officials said, including the interior minister, a top adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky, who oversaw Ukraine’s domestic security.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia
item.media:description: The scene of the helicopter crash on Wednesday in Brovary, Ukraine.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern to Resign as Prime Minister of New Zealand
item.description: Ms. Ardern, a global liberal icon who has faced rising political headwinds at home, will leave office by Feb. 7, she said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announcing her resignation in Napier, New Zealand, on Thursday.

item.title: Canada’s New Guidelines for Alcohol Say ‘No Amount’ Is Healthy
item.description: The guidance builds on growing evidence, after decades of sometimes conflicting research, that even small amounts of alcohol can have serious health consequences.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Jen Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drinking even small amounts of alcohol “is damaging to everyone, regardless of age, sex, gender, ethnicity, tolerance for alcohol or lifestyle,” the Canadian Centre on Substance Use and Addiction said in a report.

item.title: At Wartime Davos Forum, Calls for European Unity Are Eased by Relief
item.description: “Our energy supply for this winter is secure,” Germany’s chancellor declared as government and business leaders gathered at the World Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany at the World Economic Forum in Davos on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Officials Denounce Aleksei Navalny’s Treatment in Prison
item.description: Their open letter to President Vladimir V. Putin is the latest in a series of public appeals from within Russia, despite his crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in court via video in May last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Deadly Helicopter Crash in Ukraine
item.description: Also, why economists are alarmed about China’s demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Firemen and emergency service workers respond at the site of a helicopter crash on Wednesday in Brovary, Ukraine.

item.title: The Only H.I.V. Vaccine in Advanced Trials Has Failed. What Now?
item.description: Janssen Pharmaceuticals ended a global trial after independent experts determined the vaccine was not effective. But there are other possibilities in the pipeline, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Study of an experimental H.I.V. vaccine in Shoshaguve, South Africa, in 2016. The vaccine has now failed in a larger trial.

item.title: Russian Citizen Accused of Running Cryptocurrency Exchange Used by Criminals
item.description: The charges were part of an intensifying effort by federal law enforcement agencies, in conjunction with European partners, to combat international cryptocurrency schemes and illegal transactions.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department said the Russian citizen, Anatoly Legkodymov, oversaw an exchange that knowingly enabled criminals “to profit from their wrongdoing, including ransomware and drug trafficking.”

item.title: U.S. Warms to Helping Ukraine Target Crimea
item.description: The Biden administration is considering the argument that Kyiv needs the power to strike at the Ukrainian peninsula annexed by Russia in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Crimea is home to tens of thousands of Russian troops and numerous Russian military bases.

item.title: The Power Politics of Social Change
item.description: From civil rights and apartheid to the protest movements of today.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Israelis protesting against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new right-wing coalition in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: At Davos, Zelensky Mourns the Dead and Pleads for Help
item.description: At the start of his address, the Ukrainian president called for a minute of silence to honor the country’s minister of internal affairs.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine started his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, with a moment of silence for those killed in Wednesday’s helicopter crash in Brovary.

item.title: A French City Appeals to Madonna for Clues About a Long-Lost Painting
item.description: The painting “Diana and Endymion” disappeared from Amiens, France, more than a century ago. The city’s mayor says Madonna could hold a key to the mystery, but experts say the pop icon has nothing to do with it.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court Orders Removal of a Netanyahu Minister
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled that Aryeh Deri, a close ally of the prime minister who was convicted of tax fraud, should be removed from his posts, as the government tries to restrict the courts’ powers.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with Aryeh Deri, the leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party, during a cabinet meeting this month in Jerusalem.

item.title: China’s Self-inflicted Pain
item.description: China’s rise seemed inevitable, but now it’s hitting serious roadblocks.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morning commuters in Shanghai last September.

item.title: Tinkering with tape, a scale and a 3-D printer, one Ukrainian unit is on a quest to build the perfect grenade.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A private in the Ukrainian Army attaching a grenade to a drone in August before using it on a mission over Russian frontline positions near Pokrovske, Ukraine.

item.title: A Shrinking, Aging China May Have Backed Itself Into a Corner
item.description: A demographics challenge has been building for years, but Beijing’s preparations are lagging. Now, many worry that current measures may offer too little, too late.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Joy Dong and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Babies hold Chinese flags during a holiday celebration in Beijing in 2019. A declining birthrate and aging population have thrust China into a demographic bind.

item.title: Ukraine Minister Killed in Helicopter Crash Oversaw Some Security Forces
item.description: Denys Monastyrsky was the highest-ranking Ukrainian government official to die since Russia’s invasion began in February last year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Denys Monastyrsky, Ukraine’s minister for internal affairs, who was killed in a helicopter crash on Wednesday.

item.title: Why China’s Shrinking Population Is Cause for Alarm
item.description: China struggled for years to curtail its rapid population growth. Now that its population is declining, economists and others fear serious implications for China and countries around the world.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family cradling their child at a park in Beijing. Data released this week by the Chinese government revealed that the country’s population has begun to shrink.

item.title: Renting as a Single Woman in India: No Visitors, No Drinking, Home by 9
item.description: India says it must do more to harness women’s economic potential. A good place to start, many say, would be the many obstacles they face outside the workplace.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meera Shankar, center, rents rooms to women, with no curfew or visiting rules, in her Bengaluru apartment. Cooking with her were Navya V.P., left, and Vandana Naugain.

item.title: Zelensky will address the Davos gathering in a marathon week of diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Olena Zelenska, the wife of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: China puts on a brave face at Davos.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Liu He, a senior Chinese official, expressed confidence in his country’s economy.

item.title: Untested German Defense Minister Has Allies Watching Closely
item.description: Boris Pistorius, the new defense minister, is seen as a skilled politician but, entering a world stage on which Ukraine is at war, he may pose a risk for Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s new defense minister, in Lower Saxony on Tuesday.

item.title: Maria Ressa, Philippine Journalist, Is Acquitted of Tax Evasion
item.description: The verdict was a rare legal victory for Ms. Ressa, founder of the news site Rappler, who has been under pressure from the Philippine authorities for years.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Maria Ressa after her acquittal in Manila on Wednesday. “Hope,” she said of the verdict. “That is what it provides.”

item.title: Pentagon Sends U.S. Arms Stored in Israel to Ukraine
item.description: Israeli officials had initially expressed concerns that the move could damage its relations with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous, Ronen Bergman, John Ismay and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arming the Ukrainian military with sufficient artillery ammunition is part of a larger American-led effort to increase its overall combat power.

item.title: Ukraine Asks for More Weapons as U.S. and Allies Meet to Discuss Aid
item.description: Ukraine has a narrow window of time to retake more territory ahead of an expected Russian spring offensive, but to do that it needs weapons like armored vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Two Leopard 2 A6 heavy battle tanks and a Puma infantry fighting vehicle at a military training ground last year in Munster, Germany.
